Lack of evidence from credible sources: The expert mentions that no other news outlet reported on the incident, which would have been a major story if it had actually occurred. This lack of corroboration from reputable sources casts doubt on the authenticity of the claim.
Inaccurate information in the article: The expert points out that the article contains false information, such as the name of the restaurant ("Komonawannafeedya") not being found in any records in Hawaii. This discrepancy raises suspicions about the veracity of the claim.
Misleading photograph: The expert highlights that the photograph included in the article, supposedly showing the breakfast Obama could have had if he were welcome at the restaurant, was actually taken at a different restaurant in 2008. This misleading use of an unrelated image further undermines the credibility of the claim.
Reputation of the source: The expert reveals that the website publishing the article, DCPosts.com, is a rebranded version of Departed.co, which has a history of publishing baseless and inaccurate articles. This information about the source's lack of credibility adds another layer of doubt to the claim's authenticity.
